keyword: Human-Computer Interaction: Computer Science-Based Breakdown
1. Interaction Design
User Interface (UI) Design: The process of making interfaces in software with a focus on looks or style.
Graphical User Interface (GUI): A form of user interface that allows users to interact with electronic devices through graphical icons.
Voice User Interface (VUI): Interfaces that allow users to interact with a system through voice commands.
Tangible User Interface (TUI): Interfaces where users interact with digital information through the physical environment.
User Experience (UX) Design: The process of enhancing user satisfaction by improving the usability, accessibility, and pleasure provided in the interaction.
Information Architecture: The structural design of shared information environments.
Wireframes: Visual guides that represent the skeletal framework of a UI.
2. Input Devices
Keyboard: A device used to input text and characters.
Mouse: A pointing device that detects two-dimensional motion relative to a surface.
Touchscreen: A display that can detect the location of touches within the display area.
Motion Sensors: Devices that detect physical movement, often used in gaming and VR.
Voice Recognition Systems: Systems that interpret and process human speech.
3. Output Devices
Monitor: A display device for visual output from a computer.
Speakers: Devices for audio output.
Printers: Devices that produce physical copies of digital documents.
Haptic Feedback Devices: Devices that provide tactile feedback to the user.
4. Interaction Paradigms
Direct Manipulation: Interaction style that involves manipulating objects on the screen.
Drag and Drop: A pointing device gesture in which the user selects an object by grabbing it and dragging it to a different location.
WIMP (Windows, Icons, Menus, Pointer): A paradigm for user interfaces based on the idea of windows, icons, menus, and pointing devices.
Natural User Interfaces (NUI): Interfaces that allow users to interact using natural behaviors, like gestures and voice commands.
Gesture Recognition: Interpreting human gestures via mathematical algorithms.
Voice Command Systems: Systems that allow interaction through spoken commands.
5. User-Centered Design
User Research: Methods for understanding users' needs and contexts.
Personas: Fictional characters created to represent different user types.
Scenarios: Stories about users and their interactions with the system.
Usability Testing: Evaluating a product by testing it on users.
Think-Aloud Protocol: A method where users speak their thoughts while performing tasks.
6. Accessibility
Assistive Technologies: Devices or software designed to assist people with disabilities.
Screen Readers: Software that reads text displayed on a screen aloud.
Braille Displays: Devices that provide a tactile output for blind users.
Universal Design: Designing products to be usable by all people, to the greatest extent possible, without adaptation.
7. Cognitive Models
GOMS (Goals, Operators, Methods, and Selection Rules): A model for human-computer interaction that describes a user's cognitive structure.
Fitts' Law: A predictive model of human movement in HCI.
Hick's Law: The time it takes for a person to make a decision increases with the number and complexity of choices.
8. Evaluation Methods
Heuristic Evaluation: A method where experts use rules of thumb to evaluate the usability of an interface.
Nielsenâ€™s Heuristics: A set of ten usability principles.
Cognitive Walkthrough: A method for evaluating the user interface by having evaluators go through tasks and see if users can achieve their goals.
A/B Testing: Comparing two versions of a web page to see which one performs better.
9. Interactive Systems
Dialog Systems: Systems designed to converse with human users.
Chatbots: Programs that simulate human conversation.
Virtual Assistants: AI systems like Siri or Alexa that assist users through voice interaction.
Collaborative Systems: Systems designed to facilitate group work.
Groupware: Software designed to help people working on a common task.
10. Emerging Technologies
Virtual Reality (VR): A simulated experience that can be similar to or completely different from the real world.
Augmented Reality (AR): An interactive experience where the objects in the real world are enhanced by computer-generated perceptual information.
Mixed Reality (MR): The merging of real and virtual worlds to produce new environments and visualizations.
Brain-Computer Interface (BCI): Direct communication pathway between an enhanced or wired brain and an external device.
11. Ethical and Social Implications
Privacy: Protecting user data and ensuring it is not misused.
Data Anonymization: Techniques to ensure that individual user data cannot be traced back to the user.
Bias and Fairness: Ensuring interfaces are inclusive and do not perpetuate biases.
Algorithmic Fairness: Ensuring algorithms treat all users fairly.
Digital Wellbeing: Ensuring technology use does not negatively impact users' mental and physical health.
